IPFS-SHRINKWRAP

back up your npm dependencies on the permanent web.

Who knows when npm will explode?

Do you trust npm to host all your dependencies over the course of decades, centuries, millenia?

ipfs-shrinkwrap uses IPFS to shrinkwrap all of your dependencies, creating a single, permanent IPFS content address to refer to everything in node_modules/.

install it!

npm install -g ipfs-shrinkwrap

use it!

From your project directory: 

ipfs-shrinkwrap

This will place an IPFS hash (content address) in your package.json file: 

{
  "name": "my-project",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "dependencies": {
    "minimist": "^1.2.0"  
  },
  "ipfs-shrinkwrap": 
  "QmcuLYBLVe99RrB..."
}

The hash will point to whatever the contents of your node_modules/ directory were at the time the shrinkwrap was done.

Now, after the npm-pocalypse, you can: 

ipfs-shrinkwrap install

To install all of your dependencies from IPFS.

it is a lifestyle

Put a badge on your README to show the world that your package is npm-pocalypse-proof! 

[![ipfs-shrinkwrap](https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmXV8a5eSGeKBCQjFzsMGyYmoYvshyX8SYBb9JCTEsr7gE)](https://github.com/elsehow/ipfs-shrinkwrap)

Keep your shinkwrap up to date, automatically! Add ipfs-shrinkwrap to the prepublish hook in your package.json: 

{ 
  scripts: {
    "prepublish": "ipfs-shrinkwrap"
  }
}

Use small modules and make your dependencies permanent......worse is better. peace
